Maintaining Dignity with personal care or any contact with a patient ............................ 8
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to ensuring that all service users are treated with privacy, dignity and respect, with due recognition to the different needs of all individuals equally, regardless of age, sexual orientation, gender, race, disability, religion, belief, gender reassignment, pregnancy and maternity or marital or civil partnership status (The Equality Act 2010).

The NHS constitution (2013) sets out a number of rights, which include rights explicitly by law and rights derived from legal obligations imposed on NHS bodies and other healthcare providers. One of these rights outlined is; “You have the right to be treated with dignity and respect, in accordance with your human rights”. Therefore healthcare workers are legally required to maintain patient's dignity at all times.

Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014, CQC regulation 10 dignity and respect is to make sure that people using the service are treated with respect and dignity at all times while they are receiving care and treatment. To meet this regulation, providers must make sure that they provide care and treatment in a way that ensures people's dignity and treats them with respect at all times. This includes making sure that people have privacy when they need and want it, treating them as equals and providing any support they might need to be autonomous, independent.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to reinforce the following principles:
You must be treated with dignity and respect at all times while you're receiving care and treatment.
You have privacy when you need and want it.
Everybody is treated as equals.
You're given any support you need to help you remain independent and involved in your local community.
Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014: Regulation 10

2.2.1 The intention of this regulation is to make sure that people using the service are treated with respect and dignity at all times while they are receiving care and treatment. To meet this regulation, providers must make sure that they provide care and treatment in a way that ensures people's dignity and treats them with respect at all times. This includes making sure that people have privacy when they need and want it, treating them as equals and providing any support they might need to be autonomous, independent and involved in their local community.
2.2.2 Providers must have due regard to the protected characteristics as defined in the Equality Act 2010.
Definitions

Freedom from intrusion and related to all information and practice that is personal or sensitive in nature to an individual.
The humane quality of having empathy and sympathy towards people, demonstrated through having positive regard for fellow Humans.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities within the Trust

High Impact Action Nutrition Group – Dignity related incidents / complaints are discussed at this meeting and actions taken back to the wards/departments for dissemination to staff. The Trust's Dignity Champion Group will have responsibility for the on-going communication and monitoring of the best practice standards.

Dementia Steering Group – Dignity related incidents / complaints are discussed at this meeting and actions taken back to the wards/departments for dissemination to staff. The Trust's Dignity Champion Group will have responsibility for the on-going communication and monitoring of the best practice standards.

Equality Diversity and Inclusion Group (EDIG) – Any serious dignity related incidents / complaints (of an EDIG nature) can be discussed at this meeting and actions taken back to the wards/departments for dissemination to staff. The Equality Diversity and Inclusion Manager attends the Patient Experience working group where any day to day concerns can be addressed.
Chief Executive
As the Trust's accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the organisation meets its legal and quality standards, therefore, sustaining high quality patient care to all.
Associate Directors of Nursing and Midwifery/Matrons

Are responsible for ensuring that the requirement of the Delivering Same Sex Accommodation Policy is effectively managed within their directorate and that their staffs are aware of and implement those requirements. Should there be a breach in the same sex accommodation Policy which is not clinically justified, an incident form and a Root Cause Analysis investigating report must be completed. Mitigating actions to maintain the patient's privacy and dignity are outlined in the regional guidance for Mixed Sex Occurrence.
Line Managers.
To ensure that positive role modelling occurs within departments.
To ensure that systems are in place to make care patient focussed.
To ensure that service user feedback is disseminated appropriately and any actions necessary are implemented.
That all breaches of policy are handled and reported appropriately.
All Staff
To maintain the privacy, dignity, respect, compassion and safeguarding for all patients at all times.
Be aware that privacy, dignity, respect and compassion are applicable to service users and visitors equally.
New Health care support workers will need to complete the Dignity in Care component of the Care Certificate.

Be polite, helpful and will treat patients, relatives and each other with respect and dignity in a manner that is non-discriminatory, regardless of gender, sexual orientation, race, culture, religious belief or age.
Challenge/report behaviour which does not promote/ensure privacy, dignity, respect and compassion.
Assessment and intervention for dignity
Staff will maintain patient dignity from the moment they come into contact with any patient and continue to do so through the patient's journey. This will take place with the following actions:
Staff will introduce themselves on initial contact with patients, including phone conversations stating their name and role.
Staff must wear identification badges, Trust approved lanyards at all times and adhere to the Trust dress code policy.

Staff will ask each patient how they wish to be addressed e.g. Mrs/Ms/Miss/Mr/first name and avoid over-familiar titles such as ‘dear', ‘love' or ‘petal', unless this is acceptable to, and agreed by the patient.
Patients' personal space is respected and promoted at all times and boundaries identified.
Listen carefully in order to understand and respond to the needs of those in our care.
Staff should be aware of individual patient's communication needs and support required. Please refer to Accessible Information Standards Policy or equivalent.
Staff should ensure patients who are non-English speaking; have access to appropriate support/translation services (Accessible Information, Translation and Interpreting).
Staff should use the information in patient documents to enhance the care and treatment plan for every patient engagement. (This Me, Hospital Passport Advance Directives and Peace Plan.
Precautions should be taken to prevent information being shared inappropriately or inadvertently i.e. computer screens being viewed and patient information on teletracking.
Consideration should be made when discussing patient care over the telephone or at work stations to ensure compliance to Protection and Code of Confidentiality Policy.
Those patients with limited knowledge and understanding will have their diagnosis, care and treatment explained to them in a manner that they are able to understand and that does not demean them.

Staff should be respectful of each patient's individual needs including mental capacity, best interest process for decision making, religious and cultural beliefs. Please refer to the MCA Act policy or equivalent.

When discussing personal information staff should be aware of the need to consider discussing matters with the patient in a private room out of the ward bay with the relevant health care professionals present.
Maintaining Dignity with personal care or any contact with a
patient including eating and drinking needs
Appropriate consent will be obtained prior to any treatment or care being given to an individual following the MCA Act Policy, refer to site polices for consent.
Ensuring that patients are able to eat their meals without any interruptions, in line with the Trust's Protected patient mealtimes policy.
Clinical interventions should be performed either prior to the mealtime or after the patient has finished their meal, to ensure that the patient's care and length of stay is not avoidably lengthened.
Where possible, planning the delivery of their care around the patient's nutritional needs.
Patients experience excellence of care in all aspects of hydration and nutritional assistance while maintaining patients' dignity and respect at all times.
Dealing with patients' request for assistance promptly. Where there is unavoidable short delay, ensure an apology is given.
Patients will be informed where there is a need for personal contact (touch) and the reason for this contact following the Chaperone policy or equivalent.

Staff should ensure that privacy and modesty are effectively maintained by using appropriate room curtains or screens and ensure adequate clothing in all settings and when the patients are in transfer
When personal care is being given, staff will use appropriate covering where possible and ensure they are not interrupted by other health care workers who are not assisting with the personal care.
Staff must ensure appropriate positioning of the patient to avoid inappropriate exposure of any bodily parts

In-patients must be able to choose what personal clothing they wish to wear and have access to their own clothes. A small supply of nightwear and personal clothing must be encouraged to be brought in to enable dignity to be maintained in an emergency.
Staff should not have personal conversations with co-workers that exclude the patient and no inappropriate conversations or words should be used in front of patients.
Staff should not use mobile phones during direct patient care.
Staff will ensure that all options have been considered with regards to elimination to ensure dignity is maintained at all times.
Staff must never leave patients exposed when they are not appropriately dressed and covered if in bed.

Incontinence aids should only be used when all other options have been considered to meet the elimination needs of the patient. Decision to use incontinence aids should involve the patient where possible and it must be evidenced that incontinence aids are in the best interest of the patient. Clearly documents and regularly reviewed that the use of incontinence aids is still appropriate.
All staff must ensure and encourage the patients independence at all times, unless they are assessed as unable to do so.

All patients will have their gender toilets available to them without having to walk past patients of the opposite sex apart from exceptions outlined in the same sex accommodation policy. Staff should ensure that patients are nursed within same sex accommodation.

Trans gender people should be accommodated according to their presentation (the way they dress, and the name and pronouns that they currently use), it applies to toilet and bathing facilities (except, for instance, that pre-operative trans people should not share shower facilities). Staff should follow the Delivering Same-sex Accommodation Regional Mixed-Sex Occurrences Policy.
Where patients have to leave the ward for investigations or necessary appointments, staff will ensure they are appropriately dressed and appropriately covered.
Patients who are transferred around the hospital who have a catheter will have this emptied prior to transfer and have the catheters appropriately covered for their journey.
Mental capacity/ consent

During day to day care of an individual, an individual needs to validly consent to that care. However, it is recognised that in practice some individuals may lack the mental capacity to make decisions around day to day care, such as consenting to hygiene needs or eating and drinking. It would impact on care to gain consent and assess capacity on every single occasion that assistance is required. Assessments of mental capacity regarding day to day decisions should be carefully recorded but does not require assessment on the Trust approved MCA form, but can be recorded in the individuals care plan or case notes.

Simple day to day decisions can be made by the decision maker in the person's best interest if there is a reasonable belief that the individual lacks capacity. The decision and action must be reflected by good documentation in the patient's

best interests, evidencing how the decision of capacity was reached. Due regard must be given to the Mental Health Act code of practice 1983 and 2007 and to the Mental Capacity Act 2005 Code of Practice and Deprivation Of Liberty Policy MSEPO-21117 as appropriate. This policy must be referred to for complex decisions which will require a full mental capacity assessment.
Staff should consider the patients privacy and dignity when assessing the need for Enhanced supervision, including the allocation most appropriate team members to carrying out the role.
Accessible information / communication

It would be wrong to assume that because a service user is unable to communicate effectively, they cannot make decisions. In situations where service users are unable to communicate their wishes, staff should look for other indicators or ways of communicating. It is a staff member responsibility to act in the patients best interest at all times if they are unable to maintain their own privacy and dignity. This includes all activities of daily living.

All organisations that provide NHS or adult social care must follow the Accessible Information Standard by law. The Accessible Information Standard aims to make sure that disabled people have access to information that they can understand and any communication support they might need.
As part of the Accessible Information Standard, organisations that provide NHS or adult social care must do five things.
They must:
Ask people if they have any information or communication needs and find out how to meet their needs.
Record those needs in a set way.
Highlight a person's file, so it is clear that they have information or communication needs, and clearly explain how those needs should be met.
Share information about a person's needs with other NHS and adult social care providers, when they have consent or permission to do so.
Make sure that people get information in an accessible way and communication support if they need it.
There are accessible resources available on intranet and internet that may support the patient. (Please see accessible information policy for your site).
The law and dignity

Dignity was initially framed by Amnesty International in 1948 as a basic human right for all and the right to dignity and respect is established by the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR, 1953). The right to be treated with dignity and respect is derived from the rights conferred by the ECHR, as given effect in UK law by the Human Rights Act 1998. The relevant rights under the ECHR are the right to life (Article 2), the right not to be subject to inhuman or degrading treatment (Article 3) and the right to respect for private and family life (Article 8). It is unlawful for a public body to act incompatibly with those ECHR rights (section 6 of the Human Rights Act, 1998).

Within nursing the regulatory body enforcing the obligation to maintain patients' dignity is the Nursing and Midwifery Council ‘The Code' (2015) .The code states that Nurses and Midwives on the register should make treating patients as individuals and respecting their dignity as their first concern.

In 2006 the Department of Health launched the Dignity in Care Campaign following a series of damning reports where Dignity and Respect was not being given to service users. The Campaign is aimed at promoting Dignity in all health and social care settings by encouraging people to sign up as Dignity Champions and pledge to make things better in their area of work.
Dignity standards

People using adult NHS services are treated with empathy, dignity and respect. (NICE 2012). This is also fundamental for developing good relationships between people providing services and those having care and treatment. The Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014 made it a statutory requirement that all people who use services are treated with dignity and respect, and the NHS Constitution for England states that patients have the right to be treated with respect and dignity.
CQC Regulation 10: Dignity and respect- Service users must be treated with dignity and respect:
When people receive care and treatment, all staff must treat them with dignity and respect at all times. This includes staff treating them in a caring and compassionate way.

All communication with people using services must be respectful. This includes using or facilitating the most suitable means of communication and respecting a person's right to engage or not to engage in communication.
Staff must respect people's personal preferences, lifestyle and care choices.

When providing intimate or personal care, provider must make every reasonable effort to make sure that they respect people's preferences about who delivers their care and treatment, such as requesting staff of a specified
gender.
People using the service should be addressed in the way they prefer.
People using the service must not be neglected or left in undignified situations.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements for existing staff. New Health care support workers will need to complete the Dignity in Care component of the Care Certificate.
Monitoring and audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Professional Nursing and Midwifery Forum, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Professional Nursing and Midwifery Forum the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
